stem: An acceptable anchorage for a fall‑arrest system is typically:

choices.text: A conduit or handrail
An engineered or structural anchorage point
Any pipe overhead
The nearest ladder rung

rationales.CHOICE-2: An engineered or structural anchorage point

stem: Which condition requires removing a chain sling from service?

choices.text: Manufacturer’s tag present
Links stretched or bent
Paint markings intact
Sling recently cleaned

rationales.CHOICE-2: Links stretched or bent

stem: Compared with a basket hitch, a choker hitch of the same sling typically:

choices.text: Has higher capacity
Has lower capacity
Has identical capacity
Cannot be used for lifting

rationales.CHOICE-2: Has lower capacity

stem: Before lifting an irregular load, you should locate the center of gravity so that:

choices.text: The hook is below the COG
The hook is directly above or slightly past the COG toward the heavy end
The hook is far to one side
COG position is irrelevant

rationales.CHOICE-2: The hook is directly above or slightly past the COG toward the heavy end

stem: Which statement about crane hand signals is correct?

choices.text: Only the operator may signal a stop
Anyone may give the universal emergency stop signal
Two hands above head always mean 'speed up'
There are no standard hand signals for cranes

rationales.CHOICE-2: Anyone may give the universal emergency stop signal

stem: When traveling with a load on a forklift, you should:

choices.text: Carry the load high for visibility
Carry the load low and tilted back
Travel fast to reduce time under load
Turn on ramps with the load elevated

rationales.CHOICE-2: Carry the load low and tilted back

stem: Before using a chain fall/lever hoist, you should:

choices.text: Oil the brake surfaces
Check the brake/pawl function with a light test lift
Remove the nameplate to reduce weight
Use a cheater bar on the lever

rationales.CHOICE-2: Check the brake/pawl function with a light test lift

stem: Before using a full‑body harness, you should:

choices.text: Ignore small cuts in webbing
Check webbing, stitching, and hardware; remove if damaged
Tie knots to shorten lanyards
Use any carabiner from the hardware store

rationales.CHOICE-2: Check webbing, stitching, and hardware; remove if damaged

stem: When climbing a ladder, which practice is correct?

choices.text: Carry tools in your hands
Maintain three points of contact
Lean far to the side to reach
Stand on the top cap for better height

rationales.CHOICE-2: Maintain three points of contact

stem: What is the recommended setup angle for a straight ladder?

choices.text: 1:1 (about 45°) against the support
4:1 (about 75°) slope from the base to the support
Lean as steep as possible to save space
Lay it nearly horizontal for stability

rationales.CHOICE-2: 4:1 (about 75°) slope from the base to the support

stem: When a portable ladder is used for access to a higher level, you should:

choices.text: Stop it flush with the landing edge
Extend above the landing and secure it to prevent movement
Place it on boxes to gain height
Grease the feet so it slides into position

rationales.CHOICE-2: Extend above the landing and secure it to prevent movement

stem: Around electrical hazards, which ladder choice is safest?

choices.text: Metal ladder
Wet wooden ladder
Fiberglass ladder in good condition
Any ladder will do

stem: Which statement about crane operations is correct?

choices.text: It is acceptable to ride the hook for short distances
Only supervisors may ride the load
No one may ride the hook or suspended load
Riding is permitted with a harness

rationales.CHOICE-3: No one may ride the hook or suspended load

stem: During a lift with a crane or hoist, bystanders should:

choices.text: Walk under the suspended load quickly
Stand close to guide by hand
Stay out of the fall zone and use barriers/tag lines
Ride on the hook for better view

rationales.CHOICE-3: Stay out of the fall zone and use barriers/tag lines

stem: If rigging gear’s history or condition is unknown, you should:

choices.text: Use it for a light lift first
Assume it’s fine if it looks clean
Remove it from service and have it inspected
Paint it and put it back

rationales.CHOICE-3: Remove it from service and have it inspected

stem: On platforms at height, which protection is appropriate?

choices.text: No guardrails if you’re careful
Guardrails and toeboards as required
Loose ropes instead of rails
Just caution tape

rationales.CHOICE-2: Guardrails and toeboards as required

stem: Before using a scaffold, a best practice is to:

choices.text: Assume it’s safe if present
Check that it’s tagged/inspected by a competent person
Jump to test deflection
Remove guardrails to work faster

rationales.CHOICE-2: Check that it’s tagged/inspected by a competent person

stem: For a two‑leg sling connection using a shackle, a good practice is:

choices.text: Load on the pin with side loading
Place the bow on the sling side to reduce side‑loading the pin
Use any random orientation
Replace shackles with padlocks

rationales.CHOICE-2: Place the bow on the sling side to reduce side‑loading the pin

stem: Why use a shock‑absorbing lanyard in fall arrest?

choices.text: To increase arrest forces
To reduce forces on the body during a fall
To make the lanyard heavier
To replace anchor points

rationales.CHOICE-2: To reduce forces on the body during a fall

stem: How does sling angle affect tension in a two-leg lift?

choices.text: Smaller angles reduce tension in each leg
Smaller angles increase tension in each leg
Angle has no effect on leg tension
Larger angles always increase tension

rationales.CHOICE-2: Smaller angles increase tension in each leg

stem: How should synthetic web slings be protected on sharp edges?

choices.text: No protection needed
Use padding/edge protectors
Wrap with tape only
Move faster to avoid cuts

rationales.CHOICE-2: Use padding/edge protectors

stem: Which statement about stepladders is correct?

choices.text: Standing on the top cap is allowed
Use them closed like a straight ladder
Do not stand on the top or top step unless designed for it
Always lean them against walls

rationales.CHOICE-3: Do not stand on the top or top step unless designed for it

stem: What is the primary purpose of using tag lines on suspended loads?

choices.text: To increase the load weight
To steer and control load swing at a distance
To tie off the crane hook
To measure load temperature

rationales.CHOICE-2: To steer and control load swing at a distance

stem: When the exact weight of a load is unknown, what is the safest approach?

choices.text: Guess the weight by the size of the load
Use rated slings and perform a short, controlled trial lift
Lift quickly to avoid swinging
Ride on the load to watch clearances

rationales.CHOICE-2: Use rated slings and perform a short, controlled trial lift

stem: Two‑leg lift of 1.2 t; each leg at 30° from horizontal. What is the tension in one leg? (round to 0.1 t; use T = W/(2·sinθ))
Load 1.0 t lifted by two legs at 60° from horizontal. Tension per leg? (round to 0.01 t)
Calculate required fall clearance: lanyard 1.8 m + deceleration 1.1 m + D‑ring‑to‑sole 1.5 m + sag 0.3 m + safety margin 1.0 m. Total?
Access height to support is 4.0 m. What base setback is required by the 4:1 rule?
A sling’s straight (vertical) WLL is 2.0 t. As a choker (~80% typical), the approximate allowable load is:
A part of unknown weight must be lifted. Choose the best sequence.

choices.text: Go straight to full lift—no time to wait
Verify slings/shackles/angles → set exclusion zone and tag lines → short trial lift a few cm to check balance/brakes → correct as needed → only then proceed
Ask someone to stand on the load for balance
Lift quickly and drive over people to save time

rationales.CHOICE-2: Verify slings/shackles/angles → set exclusion zone and tag lines → short trial lift a few cm to check balance/brakes → correct as needed → only then proceed

stem: For a JHA/toolbox talk before rigging a plate, which step‑wise plan is best?

choices.text: Rig and pull immediately; discussion wastes time

Identify sharp edges/splinters (gloves, edge pads) → pinch hazards during sling assembly (hands out of pinch plane) → fall zone/swing (tag lines, barriers) → comms with operator/signal person → balance check on trial lift
Play music so everyone can hear
Rely on experience without discussion

rationales.CHOICE-2: Identify sharp edges/splinters (gloves, edge pads) → pinch hazards during sling assembly (hands out of pinch plane) → fall zone/swing (tag lines, barriers) → comms with operator/signal person → balance check on trial lift

stem: You encounter a scaffold with a missing/red tag. Proper action:

choices.text: Proceed if it looks ‘OK’
Do not use; barricade/notify; request inspection by a competent person and correct tagging
Add a board and keep working
Remove guardrails so they don’t interfere

rationales.CHOICE-2: Do not use; barricade/notify; request inspection by a competent person and correct tagging

stem: Work at height on a beam is planned. Best pre‑work plan:

choices.text: Clip to the nearest pipe
Select a rated anchor and verify fall clearance → inspect harness/lanyard/carabiner → plan post‑fall rescue → protect against sharp edges (lanyard extenders/edge‑rated gear) → then tie‑off and work
Use knots to shorten the lanyard
Remove the energy absorber—it gets in the way

rationales.CHOICE-2: Select a rated anchor and verify fall clearance → inspect harness/lanyard/carabiner → plan post‑fall rescue → protect against sharp edges (lanyard extenders/edge‑rated gear) → then tie‑off and work

stem: Driving a forklift on a ramp with a load. What is correct?

choices.text: Turn on the slope to save time
Keep the load uphill, low, and tilted back; travel slowly; do not turn on the slope
Always reverse downhill regardless of visibility
Raise the load high for better view

rationales.CHOICE-2: Keep the load uphill, low, and tilted back; travel slowly; do not turn on the slope

stem: Before tensioning with a lever hoist, choose the correct pre‑use sequence:

choices.text: Grease the brake, wrap chain over the hook, then pull
Inspect hook/latch and chain for twist/wear → ensure straight‑line pull → light trial lift to verify brake → then work within WLL
Load to the limit immediately; the brake will self‑check
Use a pipe cheater on the handle

rationales.CHOICE-2: Inspect hook/latch and chain for twist/wear → ensure straight‑line pull → light trial lift to verify brake → then work within WLL

stem: A 3‑leg bridle is used, but due to geometry only TWO legs carry the load. Load weight is 2.0 t. Each loaded leg is at 45° from horizontal. What is the tension in one loaded leg? (use T = W/(2·sinθ); round to 0.01 t)
You must lift a rectangular frame with a 4‑leg bridle; two legs will carry the load and two will stabilize. Choose the best plan.

choices.text: Use very small angles to the horizontal (<30°) so slings are tight; grab thin edges without protection

Treat the lift as a 2‑leg calculation; equalize leg lengths with a master link/spreader; keep angle to horizontal ≥60° (or to vertical ≤30°); protect edges; use tag lines to stabilize; avoid side‑loading the shackle pin
Choke the frame around thin flanges for a ‘better grip’
Lift without tag lines—stabilization is unnecessary

rationales.CHOICE-2: Treat the lift as a 2‑leg calculation; equalize leg lengths with a master link/spreader; keep angle to horizontal ≥60° (or to vertical ≤30°); protect edges; use tag lines to stabilize; avoid side‑loading the shackle pin

stem: A load on a forklift completely blocks forward view; an aisle intersection is ahead. Choose the correct actions.

choices.text: Drive forward with the load raised to see over it
Travel in reverse with the load low and tilted back; sound the horn at the intersection; slow down; if visibility is limited, use a spotter
Cut through a pedestrian zone without signaling to avoid delays
Have a coworker walk directly in front of the forks as a guide

rationales.CHOICE-2: Travel in reverse with the load low and tilted back; sound the horn at the intersection; slow down; if visibility is limited, use a spotter
